title: Playground
text:
This page is a playground with all R packages in the installation guide already installed. It may take a while to download all the required packages.
This page is only useful if your computer does not have R or you cannot install all the R packages necessary for the workshop. Otherwise, you can just run the code in your own computer.

title: Simple linear regression
section: Exercise 3.1: Mammal body and brain size
text:
Exercise 3.1: Mammal body and brain size
Consider the mammal dataset which contains the body weight in kg and brain weight in grams of 62 mammals. This data is avaiable by typing mammal in this exercise consoles.














Note



Check your data first before modelling!



Exercise 3.1.1
First let’s look at the numerical summary of the data. In particular, check if there are any missing values, unusual values or outliers.











skimr::skim(mammal)
skimr::skim(mammal)








Exercise 3.1.2
Next, let’s look at the graphical summaries of the data. Create a scatter plot of brain weight against body weight.











ggplot(mammal) +
  aes(body, brain) +
  geom_point()
ggplot(mammal) +
  aes(body, brain) +
  geom_point()








Exercise 3.1.3
Looks like there are a few points that have much larger body and brain weight. Let’s consider taking a log transformation for both \(x\) and \(y\) axis.











ggplot(mammal) +
  aes(body, brain) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_y_log10() +
  scale_x_log10()
ggplot(mammal) +
  aes(body, brain) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_y_log10() +
  scale_x_log10()








Exercise 3.1.4
What is the correlation between the log of body and the log of brain weight? Calculate using the log with base 10.









The correlation is pretty high!


cor(log10(mammal$body), log10(mammal$brain))
cor(log10(mammal$body), log10(mammal$brain))
















Exercise 3.1.5
Let’s fit a simple linear regression model to predict brain weight from body weight and look at the summary of the model.















Hint





Did you take the log transformation of the variables?
lm(log10(brain) ~ ______, data = mammal)







fit <- lm(log10(brain) ~ log10(body), data = mammal)
summary(fit)
fit <- lm(log10(brain) ~ log10(body), data = mammal)
summary(fit)










Based on the above the fitted model is:
\[\log_{10}(\hat{\texttt{brain}}) = 0.927 + 0.752 \times \log_{10}(\texttt{body})\] or transforming back to the original scale:
\[\hat{\texttt{brain}} = 10^{0.927 + 0.752 \times \log_{10}(\texttt{body})}\]






Exercise 3.1.6
Let’s have a look at some model diagnostics to see if there are any issues with the model. Create some plots to assess the assumption that the errors are independently and identically normally distributed. Do you have any concerns about the model fit?









The residuals look approximately normally distributed (as indicated by the bell curve shape in the histogram and Q-Q plot). There are no noticeable trends or unusual patterns that can be seen in the residual plots.








Okay, given that we observe no violations of the model assumptions from above, let’s proceed with some inferences from this model.



Exercise 3.1.7
What is the 95% confidence interval for the slope of the model? You don’t need to transform the variables back to the original scale in thie exercise.















Hint





Check out what the function confint does in R.
help(confint)





The 95% confidence interval for the slope is given as:


confint(fit, "log10(body)")
confint(fit, "log10(body)")


Or alternatively, this can be extracted using the tidy function from the broom package:














Exercise 3.1.8
Given the model from the previous exercise, predict the mean brain weight when the body weight is 100kg and its 99% confidence interval.















Hint





Note that here we have to transform the predicted value to the original scale by taking the inverse function (the inverse of the \(\log_{10}(x)\) functions is \(10^x\)). In R, the \(10^x\) function is given by 10^x where x is a numeric value.
10^predict(fit, ______, interval = "confidence", level = 0.99)





The predicted brain weight (in g) when the body weight is 100kg is:


10^predict(fit, newdata = data.frame(body = 100), 
           interval = "confidence", level = 0.99)
10^predict(fit, newdata = data.frame(body = 100), 
           interval = "confidence", level = 0.99)

title: Parametric distributions
text:
Exercise 1.1
Try simulating a sequence of 100 Bernoulli trials with a success probability of 0.3.











rbinom(100, 1, 0.3)
rbinom(100, 1, 0.3)










Hint 1





Bernoulli trials are a special case of binomial trials.
rbinom(______)











Hint 2





A Bernoulli trial has only one trial and the probability of success is 0.3.
How many trials do you want to simulate?
rbinom(______, 1, 0.3)

title: Parametric distributions
text:
Exercise 1.2
Now try generating a sequence of 20 random numbers, each representing the number of successes in 100 independent Bernoulli trials with a success probability of 0.3.











rbinom(20, 100, 0.3)
rbinom(20, 100, 0.3)










Hint 1





The number of successes from independent Bernoulli trials follows a binomial distribution.
rbinom(______)











Hint 2





The number of Bernoulli trials is 100 for each simulation.
How many numbers did you want to simulate?
rbinom(______, 100, 0.3)

title: Parametric distributions
text:
Exercise 1.3
Kylie Kelce is expecting a fourth baby girl. All four of her children are girls. What is the probability this occurs?











dbinom(4, 4, 0.5)
dbinom(4, 4, 0.5)










Hint 1





The sex of each child is independent of the others and the chance of either male or female sex is approximately 0.5.
dbinom(______, 4, 0.5)

title: Parametric distributions
text:
Exercise 1.4
I have 40 plants each with a 0.8 probability of surviving in a given environment. What is the probability that equal to or more than 30 plants would survive in this environment?











1 - pbinom(29, 40, 0.8)
1 - pbinom(29, 40, 0.8)










Hint 1





Remember that the converse of greater than or equal to 30 is less than or equal to 29 if we are only considering integers.
1 - pbinom(______, 40, 0.8)

title: Parametric distributions
text:
Exercise 1.5
An adult height is typically about 1.75m with standard deviation of 7cm for males in Australia. Gough Whitlam was 1.94m in height. What is the probability that a random Australian male is taller than Gough Whitlam?











1 - pnorm(194, 175, 7)
1 - pnorm(194, 175, 7)










Hint 1





Remember that the mean and standard deviation should have the same unit of measurement.
1 - pnorm(194, ______, 7)

title: Parametric distributions
text:
Exercise 1.6
In a population of a particular species of fish, the length of the fish is normally distributed with a mean of 175mm and a standard deviation of 7mm. Simulate a scenario were twenty fish were caught and measured. What proportion of fishes were longer than 194mm?
How does the proportion compare to the answer in Exercise 5?









Notice that the this scenario is similar to Exercise 5, except the proportion is calculated from a finite sample, whereas the previous exercise was calculated considering the distribution in the population.


fish_lengths <- rnorm(20, 175, 7)
mean(fish_lengths > 194)
fish_lengths <- rnorm(20, 175, 7)
mean(fish_lengths > 194)

title: Parametric distributions
text:
Exercise 1.7
For this exericse, the dplyr and ggplot2 packages have been loaded.








The sugarcane data cotains 2,056 observations of sugarcane yield from a uniformity trial. This sugarcane data is also already loaded in the exercise environment with a glimpse of the data below.
















Create a histogram of the yield variable with 30 bins but show the \(y\)-axis as a density instead of counts.











ggplot(sugarcane, aes(x = yield)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)), bins = 30, color = "white") 
ggplot(sugarcane, aes(x = yield)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)), bins = 30, color = "white") 






Estimate the mean and standard deviation of the yield variable.











sugarcane |> 
  summarise(mean = mean(yield), sd = sd(yield))
sugarcane |> 
  summarise(mean = mean(yield), sd = sd(yield))






Assuming that the yield is normally distributed with the mean and standard deviation estimated from the data, try plotting this estimated density onto the histogram with 30 bins.











ggplot(sugarcane, aes(x = yield)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)), 
                 bins = 30, 
                 color = "white") +
  geom_function(fun = \(x) dnorm(x, 
                                 mean(sugarcane$yield),
                                 sd(sugarcane$yield)),
                color = "red", linewidth = 1.5)
ggplot(sugarcane, aes(x = yield)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)), 
                 bins = 30, 
                 color = "white") +
  geom_function(fun = \(x) dnorm(x, 
                                 mean(sugarcane$yield),
                                 sd(sugarcane$yield)),
                color = "red", linewidth = 1.5)

title: Multiple linear regression
text:
Exercise 1
Does brain weight for different mammal species depend on body weight?
To answer this question the following questions use the following data



















rbinom(100, 1, 0.3)
rbinom(100, 1, 0.3)










Hint 1





Bernoulli trials are a special case of binomial trials.
rbinom(______)











Hint 2





A Bernoulli trial has only one trial and the probability of success is 0.3.
How many trials do you want to simulate?
rbinom(______, 1, 0.3)

title: Wrap-up
text:
Data dreging

title: Wrap-up
text:
Resources

Welham et al (2015) Statistical Methods in Biology: Design and Analysis of Experiments and Regression. CRC Press.
Whitlock and Schluter (2015) The Analysis of Biological Data. W. H. Freeman and Company. 2nd edition.
Faraday (2009) Linear Models with R. CRC Press.

title: Modelling with continuous responses
section: Crop yield due to nitrogen and rainfall
text:
Crop yield due to nitrogen and rainfall











200 randomly selected farms planted with the same wheat variety in a particular region recorded:

the average nitrogen content in their soil (kg/ha) and
the total amount of rainfall (mm) they received in a particular year.

The yield of wheat (tonnes/ha) was recorded for each farmer.

title: Modelling with continuous responses
text:
Exploring multivariate or multivariable data












Multivariate data: multiple dependent variables.
Multivariable data: multiple independent variables.
What is independent and dependent variable can be context specific.
In this example, we know yield is dependent on nitrogen and rainfall so we have a multivariable data.

title: Modelling with continuous responses
text:
Quadratic function

The quadratic function is a polynomial function of order 2 with the form:

y = f(x) = a + b x + c x^2




viewof a = Inputs.number({step: 0.1, value: 2, label: "a"})
viewof b = Inputs.number({step: 0.1, value: 0, label: "b"})
viewof c = Inputs.number({step: 0.1, value: 1, label: "c"})
























y =  +  x +  x^2

title: Modelling with continuous responses
section: Fitting multiple linear regression model in R
text:
Fitting multiple linear regression model in R
Assuming that x1 and x2 are numerical variables, the following model


lm(y ~ 1 + x1 + x2 + I(x2^2))

 is equivalent to fitting the model: 

y_i = \beta_01 + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + \beta_3 x_2^2 + \epsilon_i,



assuming \epsilon_i \sim NID(0, \sigma^2)
\boldsymbol{\beta} = (\beta_0, \beta_1, \beta_2, \beta_3)^\top are the coefficients to be estimated.
I() is used to indicate that x2^2 is taken as-is as another variable.
Notice the one-to-one correspondence between the symbolic model formula and the mathematical model.

title: Modelling with continuous responses
section: Goodness-of-fit measures for the additive model
text:
Goodness-of-fit measures for the additive model











R^2, also called the coefficient of determination, is the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is explained by the independent variables.
R^2 increases as the number of predictors in the model increases.
The adjusted R^2 is a modified version of R^2 that adjusts for the number of predictors in the model.
R^2 is between 0 and 1, where 1 indicates a perfect fit.

title: Modelling with continuous responses
text: Model diagnostic for M1

title: Modelling with continuous responses
text:
Interaction plot











The lines crossover slightly suggesting there may be some weak interaction effect between nitrogen and rainfall.

title: Modelling with continuous responses
text:
Fitting interaction effects in R
Assuming that x1 and x2 are numerical variables, the following model


lm(y ~ 1 + x1 + x2 + I(x2^2) + x1:x2 + x1:I(x2^2))

 is equivalent to fitting the model: 

y_i = \beta_01 + \beta_1 x_1 + \beta_2 x_2 + \beta_3 x_2^2 + \beta_4 x_1x_2 + \beta_5 x_1x_2^2 + \epsilon_i,



assuming \epsilon_i \sim NID(0, \sigma^2)
\beta_1, \beta_2 and \beta_3 are referred to as the main effects.
\beta_4 and \beta_5 are the interaction effects.

title: Modelling with continuous responses
text:
Symbolic model formula

Intercept included by default: y ~ 1 + x1 + x2 is equivalent to y ~ x1 + x2.
Removing intercept: y ~ 0 + x1 + x2 and y ~ -1 + x1 + x2 both remove the intercept term in the model.
Main and interaction effects: y ~ x1 * x2 is equivalent to y ~ x1 + x2 + x1:x2.y ~ x1 * x2 * x3 is equivalent to       y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x1:x2 + x1:x2 + x2:x3 + x1:x2:x3.
Main effects and two-way interaction effects only: y ~ (x1 + x2 + x3)^2 and y ~ x1 * x2 * x3 - x1:x2:x3 is equivalent to       y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x1:x2 + x1:x2 + x2:x3.

title: Modelling with continuous responses
text: Model diagnostics for M2

title: Modelling with continuous responses
section: Comparing to a nested model using the F-test
text:
Comparing to a nested model using the F-test

M1: \texttt{yield}_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \texttt{nitrogen}_i + \beta_2 \texttt{rainfall}_i + \beta_3 \texttt{rainfall}_i^2 + \epsilon_i  M2: \texttt{yield}_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \texttt{nitrogen}_i + \beta_2 \texttt{rainfall}_i + \beta_3 \texttt{rainfall}_i^2 + \beta_4 \texttt{nitrogen}_i \times \texttt{rainfall}_i + \qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\beta_5 \texttt{nitrogen}_i \times \texttt{rainfall}_i^2 + \epsilon_i

Hypotheses:
H_0: \beta_4 = \beta_5 = 0 (equivalent to M1) H_A: At least one of \beta_4 or \beta_5 is not equal to 0

title: Modelling with continuous responses
section: Comparing models using AIC or BIC
text:
Comparing models using AIC or BIC



If the models are not nested, we can use AIC or BIC to compare models.
Lower AIC or BIC indicates a better model.
AIC penalizes model complexity with a penalty term of 2p where p is the number of regression parameters.
BIC penalizes model complexity with a penalty term of p\log_e(n) where n is the number of observations.


AIC is better for prediction purposes, while BIC is better for explanation (usually results in a simpler model).

title: Modelling with continuous responses
text:
Model interpretation

M2: \hat{\texttt{yield}}_i = 2.41624 + 0.03161\times \texttt{nitrogen}_i + 0.04358\times \texttt{rainfall}_i -0.00005\times \texttt{rainfall}_i^2 +\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad0.00008\times \texttt{nitrogen}_i \times \texttt{rainfall}_i +0.00000\times \texttt{nitrogen}_i \times \texttt{rainfall}_i^2

title: Modelling with continuous responses
section: Data generating process for crop yield
text:
Data generating process for crop yield









M2: \hat{\texttt{yield}}_i = 2.41624 + 0.03161\times \texttt{nitrogen}_i + 0.04358\times \texttt{rainfall}_i -0.00005\times \texttt{rainfall}_i^2 +\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad0.00008\times \texttt{nitrogen}_i \times \texttt{rainfall}_i +0.00000\times \texttt{nitrogen}_i \times \texttt{rainfall}_i^2

text: Summary

title: Simple linear regression
section: Case study  Seed weight from seed length
text:
Case study  Seed weight from seed length



Seed length is expected to be a major contributor to differences in seed weight for wheat.
190 seeds selected at random from a line of diploid wheat, Triticum monococcum for length and weight.

























Data source: Welham et al. (2015) Statistical Methods in Biology: Design and Analysis of Experiments and Regression.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Correlation coefficient

The sample Pearson correlation coefficient, denoted as r, is a measure of the strength of a linear relationship between two variables (x and y).

r = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i-\bar{x})(y_i - \bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^n(x_i - \bar{x})^2\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i - \bar{y})^2}}

The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to 1.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Interpretation of correlation coefficient



The sign of the correlation coefficient indicates the direction of the relationship.




|r|
Interpretation




0.8 - 1.0
Very strong association


0.6 - 0.8
Strong association


0.4 - 0.6
Moderate association


0.2 - 0.4
Weak association


0.0 - 0.2
Very weak association






viewof nsample = Inputs.number([20, 1000], {step: 20, value: 200, label: "Number of samples"})
viewof r = Inputs.range([-1,1], {step: 0.05, value: 0.8, label: "Correlation coefficient"})

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Wrong interpretation of correlation coefficient


 Source: xkcd

Correlation doesn’t provide the direction of the relationship.
We cannot say just because x and y are highly correlated, x causes y or vice versa – correlation is not causation!



Correlation also only measures a linear relationship, so low correlation doesn’t mean that there is no relationship.










Correlation coefficient: -0.0217634

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Summary statistics can be misleading



You can have a bivariate data with the exact same marginal mean, variance and correlation but the relationship between the two variables can be very different.
Always plot your data!

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Simple linear regression

We seek to model the relationship between:

the mean of a response variable, y, and
a single explanatory variable (or predictor/covariate) x.

For observations i = 1, 2, \ldots, n:


y_i  = \beta_0 + \beta_1x_i + \epsilon_i



\boldsymbol{\beta} = \begin{bmatrix}\beta_0 \\ \beta_1\end{bmatrix} are referred to as the regression parameters/coefficients.

intercept slope error for the i-th observation, and assume \epsilon_i \sim NID(0, \sigma^2), i.e. normally and independently distributed with mean 0 and variance \sigma^2.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Least Squares Estimates












Find \hat \beta_0 and \hat \beta_1 that minimize the sum of squares:

\text{RSS}(\beta_0, \beta_1) = \sum_{i=1}^n \left(y_i - (\beta_0 + \beta_1 x_i)\right)^2

The least squares estimates can be found by using calculus.
Visually, we can try changing the regression parameters below:


viewof intercept_1 = Inputs.number({step: 0.1, value: -27.9, label: "β̂₀"})
viewof slope_1 = Inputs.number({step: 0.1, value: 17.2, label: "β̂1"})

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Fitting linear models in R
\texttt{Weight}_i=\beta_0 + \beta_1\texttt{Length}_i + e_i









The least square estimates are: \hat{\beta}_0 = -27.93 and \hat{\beta}_1 = 17.17.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Fitted values













The fitted values are the red points given as:

\hat{y}_i = \hat{\beta}_0 + \hat{\beta}_1 x_i.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Predicted values













The response can be predicted from the fitted model for a given x as:

\hat{y} = \hat{\beta}_0 + \hat{\beta}_1 x.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Making inferences


The standard deviation of an estimator is referred to as the standard error.
In making inferences, you may like to know:

what is the standard error of \hat{\beta}_1?
is \beta_1 \neq 0?
what is the confidence interval of the average y for a given x?
what is the prediction interval of y for a given x?

 It’s important to note that making inferences require the assumptions of the linear regression model to be satisfied.
So check model assumptions first!

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Assumptions for linear regression

Recall for i=1,\ldots,n, \epsilon_i \sim NID(0,\sigma^2) which means:

(A1) \text{E}(\epsilon_i) = 0
(A2) \epsilon_1, \ldots ,\epsilon_n are independent.
(A3) \text{Var}(\epsilon_i) = \sigma^2 which is called the homoscedasticity assumption.
(A4) \epsilon_1, \ldots ,\epsilon_n are normally distributed
(A5) the predictors are known without error.




An unbiased estimate of \sigma is given by:

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Checking assumptions

A1 is satisfied by definition for the least squares estimates.











A2 and A3 can be checked by plotting the residuals against the fitted values and ensuring that there is no pattern or trends.












Also checked by plotting the residuals against the predictor(s).












Sometimes plotting the residuals against the order of data entry can also be useful in identifying potential violations of A2.












A4 can be checked by plotting the normal quantile-quantile plot of the residuals. If it roughly straight then A4 is satisfied.










There are no standard ways to check A5 easily.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Influence measures

The data may contain outliers, high leverage values, and other unusual values that can affect the regression model.











Let’s check the “influential” observations:












Red points are the observations to scrutinize further.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Box cox transformation



Box-cox transformation modifies the response for a given value of \lambda such that:

y(\lambda) = \begin{cases} \frac{y^{\lambda} - 1}{\lambda} & \text{if } \lambda \neq 0, \\ \log(y) & \text{if } \lambda = 0. \end{cases}


The transformation is equivalent to:




\lambda
Transformation




2
y^2


1
y


0.5
\sqrt{y}


0
\log(y)


-0.5
\sqrt{y}


-1
\frac{1}{y}


-2
\frac{1}{y^2}

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Selecting \lambda for box-cox transformation










Profile log-likelihood plot suggests \lambda \approx 0.5 which is equivalent to taking the square root of the response.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Transforming the response










Remember the fitted or predicted value need to be squared to get the original scale.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Quick diagnostic plots

An easy way to generate some of the diagnostic plots at once is to use the ggResidpanel package.











But the QQ-plot still doesn’t look good enough??

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Visual inference

When making inference from plots, it’s best to calibrate the plot with simulations.
Let’s assume that \sqrt{\texttt{Weight}} = \hat{\beta}_0 + \hat{\beta}_1 \texttt{Length} + \epsilon, where \epsilon \sim N(0, \hat{\sigma}^2) is the correct model.
Then simulate from this model 9 times:










Then let’s look at the QQ-plot of the residuals from the simulated data:

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Hypothesis testing for regression parameters

Source: xkcd

Consider testing if the j-th regression parameter is significant for j = 1, \ldots, p = 2:

H_0: \beta_j = 0 \quad \text{vs} \quad H_A: \beta_j \neq 0

Assumption: suppose the residuals are normally distributed.
The test statistic and its distribution is

\dfrac{\hat{\beta}_j - \beta_j}{\text{SE}(\hat{\beta}_j)} \sim t_{n-p}.

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Confidence interval for regression parameters

The 100(1-\alpha)\% confidence interval for the j-th regression parameter is

\hat{\beta}_j \pm t_{n-p, 1-\alpha/2} \times \text{SE}(\hat{\beta}_j).

For \alpha = 0.05, the 95% confidence interval for the regression parameters are:

title: Simple linear regression
text:
Confidence interval and prediction interval

The 95% confidence interval for the mean response at x = 5 is










The 95% prediction interval for the response at x = 5 is










The prediction interval is always wider as it considers the uncertainty in the response as well.

text:

title: Introduction to Statistics with R
text: 🎯 Learning objectives

title: Introduction to Statistics with R
text:
🔧 Software requirements
Please ensure that you have:

a computer or laptop with a stable (and preferably fast) internet connection, and
a modern web browser like Google Chrome.

In this workshop, all R code and exercises are run in the browser using Quarto live. As such, you don’t need to install R or any R packages to participate in this workshop. But should you wish to know use the R packages used, these include:
c('tidyverse', 'ggdist', 'ggbeeswarm', 'broom', 'patchwork', 'GGally', 'ggpubr',
  'emmeans', 'modelsummary', 'ggResidpanel', 'agridat', 'faraway', 'abd')

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
Distribution of data

The distribution of data can tells about the frequency of a range of values.



For discrete data, we can use a barplot to visualise the distribution.










For continuous data, we can use a histogram or density plot to visualise the distribution.










viewof nbins = Inputs.number([5, 100], {step: 1, label: "Number of bins for histogram", value: 30})








 The number of bins does affect the histogram appearance, so explore different values to see how it changes the plot.

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
Parametric distributions

Parametric distribution are defined by just a handful of parameters.













Bernoulli distribution

viewof p2 = Inputs.range([0, 1], {step: 0.01, label: "p", value: 0.5})

















Binomial distribution

viewof n = Inputs.number([1, Infinity], {step: 1, label: "n", value: 10})
viewof p = Inputs.range([0, 1], {step: 0.01, label: "p", value: 0.5})

























Poisson distribution

viewof lambda = Inputs.number([0, Infinity], {step: 0.1, label: "λ", value: 1})

















Negative binomial distribution

viewof nbsize = Inputs.number([1, Infinity], {step: 1, label: "n", value: 10})
viewof nbprob = Inputs.range([0, 1], {step: 0.01, label: "p", value: 0.5})

























Normal distribution

viewof mu2 = Inputs.number({step: 0.5, label: "μ", value: 0})
viewof sd2 = Inputs.number({step: 0.01, label: "σ", value: 1})

























t distribution

viewof df2 = Inputs.number([0, Infinity], {step: 1, label: "degrees of freedom", value: 1})

















Uniform distribution

viewof xmin = Inputs.number({step: 0.1, label: "min", value: 0})
viewof xmax = Inputs.number({step: 0.1, label: "max", value: 1})

























Gamma distribution

viewof shape = Inputs.number({step: 0.1, label: "shape", value: 1})
viewof rate = Inputs.number({step: 0.1, label: "rate", value: 1})

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
Binary events in the wild



Flipping a coin 🪙

Possible outcomes: (A) tail  or (B) head 
For an unbiased coin, probability for each outcome is 0.5.



Singleton pregnancy in women 🤰

Possible outcomes: (A) a baby girl 👧 or (B) a baby boy 👦 ignoring miscarriages, irregularities, intersex, etc
Probability for each outcome is 0.5.




Australian Federal election 🇦🇺

Possible outcomes: (A) Labor party 🔴 or (B) Liberal party 🔵 (ignoring other parties and formation of majority or minority government)
Probability for Labor party winning??



Winning a chess match ♟️

Possible outcomes: (A) Win 🏆 or (B) Lose ❌
Probability of winning depends on the skill level of the players

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
Bernoulli distribution


A random event with two possible outcomes: A or B.
The probability of A is p and the probability of B is 1-p.




A Bernoulli trial for say p = 0.5 in  is shown below:




















Or we encode A = 1 and B = 0:

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
Binomial distribution

Suppose we have n = 30 independent Bernoulli trials with p = 0.2.












The number of “successes” out of n independent Bernoulli trials with probability of success, p, follows a binomial distribution with parameters n and p.













Or we can simulate the sum directly:

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
A Binomial random variable
X = X_1 + X_2 + \cdots + X_n \sim B(n, p)

X_i \sim \text{Bernoulli}(p) where p is the probability of success,
X_i = 1 if i-th trial is a success, otherwise X_i = 0,
all the trials are independent and p is constant for all trials,
X \in \{0, 1, \ldots, n\} is the number of successes out of n trials.





Expected value: E(X) = np
Variance: \text{Var}(X) = np(1-p)
Standard deviation: \text{SD}(X) = \sqrt{np(1-p)}




Probability mass function:
P(X = x) = \binom{n}{x} p^x (1-p)^{n-x}

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
Binomial probability and distribution function

Suppose I flip an unbiased coin 10 times (so n = 10, p = 0.5).


What is the probability that exactly 3 are heads?











What is the probability that there are 3 or less heads?












What is the probability that there are 3 or more heads?

text:
Use in-silico experiments to understand statistics

Computer-based simulations are “cheap”.
Understand how statistics behave under known data-generating process.




viewof n_exp = Inputs.number([5, Infinity], {step: 1, label: "n_exp", value: 5})
viewof n_trials = Inputs.number([1, Infinity], {step: 1, label: "n_trials", value: 10})

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
Continuous data in the wild



Heights of adults











Yields of a sorghum variety at a location in India












Wheat flour retail prices in India, 2022 April











Total download of R packages on February 2024

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
Normal distribution


A continuous distribution that is symmetric and bell-shaped.
The probability density function is:

f(x; \mu, \sigma) = \frac{1}{\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}\text{exp}\left(-\frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)




X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2) where

E(X) = \mu is the mean/expected value and
\text{Var}(X) = \sigma^2 is the variance.

The standard normal distribution is N(0, 1).




viewof mu = Inputs.number({step: 0.5, label: "μ", value: 0})
viewof sd = Inputs.number({step: 0.5, label: "σ", value: 1})

























Total area under the curve = 1.

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
Probability calculation for continuous distributions

The probability of a continuous random variable falling in a specific range is the area under the curve.












P(X < 2) where X \sim N(0, 1)


















P(X > 2) where X \sim N(1, 2)


















P(0 < X < 2) where X \sim N(0, 1)

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
section: Fitting a normal distribution to data
text:
Fitting a normal distribution to data

 Yields of a sorghum variety at a location in India












Visualise a normal distribution fitted to the data:












Calculate the probability of a yield being greater than 1.5 tolas per plot:

title: Parametric distributions to describe and simulate data
text:
t distribution
 Source: xkcd

The t-distribution is a continuous distribution that is symmetric and bell-shaped, but has heavier tails than the standard normal distribution.
The t-distribution is used when the sample size is small and the population standard deviation is estimated from the sample.
The grey area is N(0, 1) for comparison.





viewof df = Inputs.number([0, Infinity], {step: 1, label: "degrees of freedom", value: 1})








As the degrees of freedom increases, the t-distribution approaches the standard normal distribution.

N(\mu, \sigma^2)

Continuous distribution that is symmetric and bell-shaped, but has heavier tails than the normal distribution
rt, dt, pt, qt



r - random number generation, d - density function, p - cumulative distribution function, q - quantile function

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Is this coin unbiased?









Suppose I have a coin that I’m going to flip 
If the coin is unbiased, what is the probability it will show heads?
Yup, the probability should be 0.5.
So how would I test if a coin is biased or unbiased?
We’ll collect some data.
Experiment 1: I flipped the coin 10 times and this is the result:





The result is 7 head and 3 tails. So 70% are heads.
Do you believe the coin is biased based on this data?

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Testing coin bias

Experiment 2: Suppose now I flip the coin 100 times and this is the outcome:



We observe 70 heads and 30 tails. So again 70% are heads.
Based on this data, do you think the coin is biased?

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Null hypothesis significance testing
Hypothesis and Assumptions

Suppose X is the number of heads out of n independent tosses.
Let p be the probability of getting a head for this coin.
Hypotheses: H_0: p = 0.5 vs. H_A: p \neq 0.5

Assumptions: Each toss is independent with equal chance of getting a head.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Null hypothesis significance testing
Test statistic, Verify and Conclusion

Test statistic: X \sim B(n, p). Recall E(X) = np. The observed test statistic is denoted x.
Verify: P-value P(\mid X - np\mid \geq \mid x - np\mid ), critical value or confidence interval
 Conclusion: Reject null hypothesis when the p-value is less than some significance level \alpha. Usually \alpha = 0.05.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
HATPC
Hypothesis, Assumption, Test statistic, V-erify, Conclusion

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Binomial test (two-sided)
H_0: p = 0.5 vs. H_A: p \neq 0.5
Assumption: each toss is independent with equal chance of getting a head.



Experiment 1

x = 7 heads, out of n = 10 tosses











The p-value is P(|X - 5| \geq 2) \approx 0.34



Experiment 2

x = 70 heads, out of n = 100 tosses











The p-value is P(|X - 50| \geq 20) \approx 0.000079.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Binomial test (one-sided)
H_0: p = 0.5 vs. H_A: p > 0.5








H_0: p = 0.5 vs. H_A: p < 0.5

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
P-values

 Reject null hypothesis when the p-value is less than some significance level \alpha.
Usually \alpha = 0.05.
The p-value is the probability of observing a test statistic as extreme as the one observed, under the null hypothesis H_0.
If the p-value is small, it suggests that the observed data is unlikely to have occurred under the null hypothesis.
A high p-value suggests that the observed data is consistent with the null hypothesis, it doesn’t mean that the null hypothesis is true.

Popular misconception:

The p-value is not the probability that the null hypothesis is true or false.
Remember that NHST is a test of significance, not a test of acceptance or truth.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Binomial proportion confidence interval

A confidence interval is a range of values that is likely to contain the true value of the parameter.


A (two-sided) 95% confidence interval for p (using Clopper and Pearson method) is given as:










If H_0: p = p_0 vs H_A: p \neq p_0 and the 100(1-\alpha)% confidence interval contains p_0, then we fail to reject the null hypothesis at \alpha significance level.
\alpha = 0.05 \rightarrow 95% confidence interval is a common choice.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Power of a hypothesis test

The power of a test is the probability of rejecting H_0 when H_A is true.

























For H_0: p = 0.5 vs. H_A: p \neq 0.5, if the number of trials is 5, then it doesn’t matter what your test statistic is, the p-value is always greater than 0.05!

 This means that this test has zero power.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Judicial system vs Statistical significance










 Evidence by test statistic
 Judgement by p-value, critical value or confidence interval

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Type 1 and 2 errors




Probability to reject H_0
Probability to not reject H_0




If H_0 is true
\alpha
1 - \alpha


If H_A is true
1 - \beta
\beta

title: Introduction to statistical inference
section: One-sample t-test: testing for the mean
text:
One-sample t-test: testing for the mean
H_0: \mu = \mu_0 vs. H_A: \mu \neq \mu_0
Sample n times from a population with mean \mu.

Assumptions: Population data is normally distributed, or otherwise the sample size n is large.
Test statistic: t = \dfrac{\bar{X} - \mu_0}{S/\sqrt{n}} \sim t_{n-1}, where:

\bar{X} is the sample mean,
S is the sample standard deviation,
n is the sample size.

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
One-sample t-test: P-value

Verify: P-value = P(|t| \geq |t^*|)

title: Introduction to statistical inference
section: Two-sample t-test: testing for the difference in means
text:
Two-sample t-test: testing for the difference in means

Sample n_1 times from population 1 with mean \mu_1.
Sample n_2 times from population 2 with mean \mu_2.
Sampling from populations 1 and 2 should be independent.

H_0: \mu_1 = \mu_2 vs. H_A: \mu_1 \neq \mu_2

Assumptions: Both populations are normally distributed (or sample sizes n_1 and n_2 are sufficiently large).
Test statistic: t = \dfrac{\bar{X}_1 - \bar{X}_2}{\sqrt{\dfrac{S_1^2}{n_1} + \dfrac{S_2^2}{n_2}}} \sim t_{n_1 + n_2 - 2}, where:

\bar{X}_i and S_i are the sample mean and standard deviation, respectively, of population i.

Verify: P-value = P(|t| \geq |t^*|)

title: Introduction to statistical inference
section: Paired t-test: testing for the difference in means
text:
Paired t-test: testing for the difference in means

Sample n times from a population with observation pairs.
d_i = X_{1i} - X_{2i} is the difference between the two observations in pair i. H_0: \mu_1 = \mu_2 vs. H_A: \mu_1 \neq \mu_2 H_0: \mu_d = 0 vs. H_A: \mu_d \neq 0

title: Introduction to statistical inference

Multiple testing

title: Introduction to statistical inference
text:
Summary

HATVC - Hypothesis, Assumption, Test statistic, Verify, Conclusion
Binomial test for testing probability of an event
t-test for comparing means
P-value, critical value or confidence interval for decision making
Statistical significance is not the same as practical significance

title: Modelling with categorical responses
text:
Exercise 1
Try simulating a sequence of 100 Bernoulli trials with a success probability of 0.3.











rbinom(100, 1, 0.3)
rbinom(100, 1, 0.3)










Hint 1





Bernoulli trials are a special case of binomial trials.
rbinom(______)











Hint 2





A Bernoulli trial has only one trial and the probability of success is 0.3.
How many trials do you want to simulate?
rbinom(______, 1, 0.3)

title: Cheatsheet
text:
Statistical inference

For Binomial proportions
For x observed number of successes and n number of trials:

binom.test(x, n, p = 0.5, alternative = "two.sided")$p.value
binom.test(x, n, conf.level = 0.95)$conf.int



For means

One-sample

t.test(x, mu = 0, alternative = "two.sided")$p.value
t.test(x, mu = 0, conf.level = 0.95)$conf.int



Two-sample

t.test(x, y, alternative = "two.sided")$p.value
t.test(x, y, conf.level = 0.95)$conf.int
t.test(x, y, var.equal = FALSE) # unequal variance (default)
t.test(x, y, var.equal = TRUE) # equal variance



Paired

t.test(x - y, alternative = "two.sided")
t.test(x, y, alternative = "two.sided", paired = TRUE)

title: Cheatsheet
text:
Exploring multivariate data

res <- correlation::correlation(data)
summary(res)
plot(res)
plot(summary(res))
GGally::ggpairs(data)

title: Cheatsheet
text:
Linear regression

x1 and x2 are continuous variables
f1 and f2 are factors
y is the response variable
data is a data frame with all of the above variables


Model fit, summary, and diagnostics

fit <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 + x1:x2, data = data)


coef(fit)
fitted(fit)
residuals(fit)
deviance(fit)
sigma(fit)
summary(fit)
cooks.distance(fit)
influence.measures(fit)
influence(fit)
confint(fit)
predict(fit, newdata = newdata, interval = "confidence", level = 0.95)

A tidy approach:

broom::tidy(fit, conf.int = TRUE, conf.level = 0.95)
broom::glance(fit)
broom::augment(fit, newdata = newdata, se.fit = TRUE, interval = "confidence", conf.level = 0.95)
ggResidpanel::resid_panel(fit)



ANOVA (regression with categorical predictors)

fit1 <- lm(y ~ f1 + f2 + f1:f2, data = data)
anova(fit1)
fit2 <- aov(y ~ f1 + f2 + f1:f2, data = data)
summary(fit2)
emm <- emmmeans::emmeans(fit1, "f1")
pairs(emm)
plot(emm)



Chi-square test

chisq.test(table(x))

M <- as.table(rbind(c(762, 327, 468), c(484, 239, 477)))
dimnames(M) <- list(gender = c("F", "M"),
                    party = c("Democrat","Independent", "Republican"))
(Xsq <- chisq.test(M))  # Prints test summary
Xsq$observed   # observed counts (same as M)
Xsq$expected   # expected counts under the null
Xsq$residuals  # Pearson residuals
Xsq$stdres     # standardized residuals



Logistic regression

fit <- glm(y ~ x1 + x2 + x1:x2, data = data, family = binomial)

title: Cheatsheet
text:
Reporting results

modelsummary::datasummary((mean + sd) * len ~ factor(dose)* supp, data = ToothGrowth)
modelsummary::modelsummary(fit)
modelsummary::modelplot(fit)
modelsummary::modelsummary(list("M1" = fit1, "M2" = fit2))
